en: Interview with Randall Brackins, chief of police for the city of Gatlinburg, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Brackins discusses the challenges faced by the Gatlinburg Police surrounding the wildfires. He recounts first being alerted to the wildfires, and the most pressing concerns for the police on the night of the disaster, and in the following days. This is a representative quote from the interview: "So we depended on our fellow law enforcement officers from all different areas to help us secure the town. And we did not allow no one in town for a few days because of security and all the dangers that were there, for instance, power lines were downed, trees were down, you couldn't go all the way through different roads or different areas."

Interview with Randall Brackins, chief of police for the city of Gatlinburg, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Brackins discusses the challenges faced by the Gatlinburg Police surrounding the wildfires. He recounts first being alerted to the wildfires, and the most pressing concerns for the police on the night of the disaster, and in the following days. This is a representative quote from the interview: "So we depended on our fellow law enforcement officers from all different areas to help us secure the town. And we did not allow no one in town for a few days because of security and all the dangers that were there, for instance, power lines were downed, trees were down, you couldn't go all the way through different roads or different areas."

none: Accompanying canvas for Interview with Randall Brackins, 2020-10-26

en: Can you state your name and tell us about your background?
Outside of your work with the police, are you involved with the community in other ways?
Could you tell us about your experiences in the weeks and months leading up to the wildfires in 2016?
When did you first become notified about a fire on Chimney Tops?
What was the significance of the meeting at Mynett Park that morning of the wildfires?
What transpired over the course of that afternoon of the wildfires?
What were the wind conditions the day of the wildfires?
What happened the evening of the wildfires?
What was going through your mind that night and what was the environment at the command center like?
What were the most urgent issues facing the police department the evening of the wildfires?
What were the challenges tha the police department faced the night of the wildfires?
Were you concerned about your family or property during that time?
Were there other communication challenges that night besides cellphone issues?
Is there anything else about the night of the wildfires that you would like to share?
What were the most urgent issues the next day?
What was your role in that whole operation over the next five days?
Are there any specific memories from interacting with people or events from those days after the fires?
How has this event impacted you personally?
What were the effects on the police department as a whole?
How did the fires shape community relations?
How would you assess the recovery of the city?
Has the police department implemented any disaster response or evacuation plans after these wildfires?
Is there anything surprising or good that came out of this event?
Is there anything surprising or good that came out of this event?
Is there anything else that you would like to share?

seo.title: Interview with Randall Brackins, 2020-10-26 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
